title: The Doctrine Of Chances: Or A Method Of Calculating The Probability Of Events In Play
description: The Doctrine of Chances, written by Abraham De Moivre and first published in 1718, is a seminal work in the field of probability theory. De Moivre's approach to probability is based on the idea of calculating the number of possible outcomes for a given event and then determining the likelihood of each outcome occurring. He also introduces the concept of expected value, which is the average outcome of a series of trials. The book is divided into three parts. The first part provides an introduction to the basic principles of probability theory, including the concept of probability and the laws of probability. The second part focuses on the application of these principles to games of chance, such as dice and cards. De Moivre provides detailed calculations for various games, including the probability of rolling certain numbers with dice and the likelihood of drawing certain cards from a deck. The third part of the book explores more advanced topics in probability theory, such as the law of large numbers and the central limit theorem. These concepts have since become fundamental to the field of statistics. Overall, The Doctrine of Chances is a groundbreaking work that laid the foundation for modern probability theory.
